resources.string: Your custom background image could not be found; the default will be used instead.
A custom background image is not defined; the default will be used instead.
Sorry, trying to set the background image has caused an out of memory error.

Welcome to BeeCount! The purpose of this app is to store count details for several knitting or crochet projects and allow you to count each separately. Each project may have multiple 'counts', each being something such as a pattern repeat or a row which you wish to track. Use the buttons below to create new projects or manage existing ones.

 By editing a project after creating it you can also link counts together so that one increments another.

Settings can be changed by accessing the menu on this screen (menu button or 3-dot overflow menu above).

Should you have any questions you may visit the Ravelry group at http://www.ravelry.com/groups/beecount, or email bug reports to knirirr@gmail.com.
Please fill in the empty boxes!
You must define at least one count!
Each count name must be unique!
Your sdcard could not be accessed!
Your database could not be exported!
Your database has been exported to the sdcard.
Your database could not be imported!
Your database has been imported from the sdcard.
Are you sure you want to import a backed-up beecount.db? Your current projects will be overwritten!
Are you sure you want to delete this project?
Sorry, your project failed to save. Please check your links and try again.
Please check which counts you have linked
The link increment value cannot be zero; save failed!
Are you sure you\'d like to do this? This count will be deleted immediately.
Are you sure you\'d like to do this? This link will be deleted immediately.
Choose default, custom or no background image.
Prevent screen from sleeping whilst counting.
Select the background image to be used when a custom image is selected.
This stops the \"x has incremented y\" toasts from popping up during counting.
Error setting custom image! Please try using the gallery rather than a file manager.
Select this option to increase the size of note fonts on the counting screen.
Sort order when viewing your list of projects.
Set the value at which this count will reset itself. The count will be reset to 0 unless the reset level (see below) is also changed. Set to 0 to disable.
When %1$s resets it will reset to the number here. To cause it to reset the auto reset value (above) must be set to a value higher than 0.
You may change the value of %1$s from its current value of %2$d by editing it here.
Each count may have zero or more alerts which will be triggered when the count reaches that level. Use the add button to the right to add more and the close button on each alert to remove it.
Are you sure you\'d like to do this? The alert will be deleted immediately.
Some of your links could not be upgraded to the new data format. Please check your projects to see which ones, and re-add them manually. Sorry for the inconvenience.
Sorry, there was a problem with your database. Please email if you need assistance, attaching your exported beecount.db.

This screen allows the calculation of increases or decreases using the \"magic formula\" - thanks to The Knitting Fiend (http://www.thedietdiary.com/blog) for permission to use these calculations. See below for more information.
Number of stitches in a row

The unbalanced method reduces sort of evenly, but the first decrease and last decreases may be different distances from the edge. Sometimes, depending on the number of stitches in the row, this \"unbalanced\" decrease happens to work out the same as the next increase. For many items, this a perfectly good method to calculate decreases. Most people can also figure out that if they take stitches from the first groups and shift them to the end, things get more balanced.\n\n The balanced method is as symmetric as possible around the center stitch. It is a pain in the neck to calculate, but it prevents your sweater hem from shifting strangely to one side. Some people don\'t ever bother to do make sure their increases are balanced and work unbalanced increases even when it matters. On the other hand, some people use the percentage method to calculate their sweaters and tolerate tight or loose sleeves, tight or loose armholes and other uncomfortable ugly knitting phenomena.
Knit %1$d, ( M1, knit %2$d) %3$d times, ( M1, knit %4$d) %5$d times, ( M1, knit %6$d) %7$d times, M1, knit %8$d.
Knit %1$d, ( k2 tog, knit %2$d ) %3$d times, ( k2 tog, knit %4$d ) %5$d times, ( k2 tog, knit %6$d ) %7$d times, k2 tog, knit %8$d.
